newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Kohl defends, plays down gold revaluation plan.
newsitem.headline: Kohl defends, plays down gold revaluation plan.

text.p: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Friday defended Germany's plans to revalue the Bundesbank's gold reserves, saying many other European Union countries already valued their reserves higher.
Kohl was asked during a summit of EU leaders whether Germany's plans to revalue the gold constituted "creative accounting" in the run-up to Europe's single currency.
Speaking at a news conference, he responded by listing values of gold in other countries.

"The price of an ounce of gold at the end of 1996 was $369," he said. "Now I will read out to you the levels at which the EU countries value gold. It will interest you. In prices per ounce, Germany is at $92, France at $370, the United Kingdom at $297, Italy at $380...."
He went on to list the book value price of gold in all other EU countries, showing that only two, Sweden and Luxembourg, used a lower value than Germany.
Revaluing the Bundesbank's gold reserves could produce a windfall profit for the government.

However, the government could not use this directly to cut the budget deficit to three percent of gross doemstic product (GDP), a key target for countries wanting to join economic and monetary union (EMU).
Pressed on whether such a revaluation at this stage posed a problem for the stability of the future European currency, Kohl said: "I do not see that at all.
"This is an accounting issue. There is a market price. We have been using the lowest price principle. Othes use the market price. I want a strong European currency."
Germany last week announced plans to revalue the Bundesbank's gold and foreign exchange reserves in a move which they say is necessary before the transfer of reserves to the European Central Bank.
The move sparked accusations from some that Germany was seeking creative ways to reduce its budget deficit.
Under EU rules, any gains from the revaluation of gold could be used to reduce debt but not as a direct contribution to offset budget spending.
Separately, Luxembourg's prime minister and finance minister Jean-Claude Juncker told reporters that he had no problem with Germany's plans to revalue its assets.
"I have no difficulty with the move as they are not selling the gold to reduce budget deficits," he said.

Kohl and Juncker were attending a summit of EU leaders and foreign ministers in the Dutch coastal resort of Noordwijk. The summit was called to assess progress in drawing up a new treaty on European integration.
